ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy. We learned about the different seasons.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of trees and other plants and sort them into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Spring shows plants that grow and flower in the spring.
Fall shows how some plants look in the fall.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra support or challenge as needed.
Encourage children to answer in complete sentences of four or more words and to use new words in their response.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend the conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the “spring” or “fall” category.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the picture cards on this side show spr (spring). How can you tell these pictures were taken in spring?
All of the picture cards on this side show f (fall). How can you tell these pictures were taken in fall?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show children three picture cards at a time, where one shows one season (e.g., fall) and the other two show the other season (e.g., spring). Ask, Which picture doesn’t belong? Then ask, How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.

Show children two picture cards at a time, where one shows spring and the other shows fall. Ask, What is the same about these pictures? What is different about them? Repeat with the other pair of cards.

Encourage children to use a physical response, in addition to speaking. For example, invite children to make a circle in front of themselves with their arms to be a pumpkin or curl their fingers to show blossoms. These physical and verbal cues will support language learners and help them participate as their language skills develop.

Consider doing this activity in a large-group space or outdoors where children can move their bodies and pretend to be the plants shown in the pictures. They could roll like a pumpkin or stretch like a growing flower. They could jump, reaching toward the sky like a tree, or use their arms and hands like falling leaves. This kind of play supports engagement and memory skills, and helps build coordination.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy, and we focused on making connections. We make connections when we connect something in a book or a picture to our own lives.
In this activity, we will act out how we would play in each scene on the picture cards. We will make connections between what we see in the pictures and what we know we like to do.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Use your body to show me what you like to do. For example, use your arms to show me how you would swim.
Think about how you would move in different weather. For example, how do you walk through snow? Through mud?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and use the text on the back to ask children what is going on in the scene and how they would play if they were in the place pictured. Offer extra support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the card to extend the conversation with children.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Making Connections Talk to children about making connections between the pictures and things they have done in their own lives. Ask children if they have ever been in a place like the ones shown in the picture (or if they have ever been in similar weather). If they have, ask whether they did activities like the ones they acted out. Ask: How does remembering that weather or activity make you feel?

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of the card. If they are unsure of how to act out an activity, offer a simpler one, such as pretending to splash in water instead of swimming. Encourage children to work together for more support.
Encourage children to work with a partner and guess what each other is doing. Then have them mirror each other’s activities and discuss why each activity would be fun in the different scenes.

Give children time for peer-to-peer conversations. Encourage children to work in pairs, talking about the activities they are acting out. Remind them to take turns speaking, with one person listening while the other person speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they both know when talking to a peer who is also multilingual.

Allow children to use drawing to show what they would do in the different scenes shown on the picture cards. Give children crayons or markers and sheets of paper so that they can respond to the scenes through art. Encourage children to talk about their pictures.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread the book Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy and focused on the weather during different seasons. We talked about how the sky and the ground change and how the air feels different during the different seasons.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of outdoor scenes and we will sort, or categorize, them into two groups.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: The “Summer” group will have scenes that happen in the summer.
The “Winter” group will have scenes that happen in the winter.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend the conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the “summer” or “winter” category.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: The picture cards on this side show s (summer). Which details helped you sort them into summer?
The picture cards on this side show w (winter). Which details helped you sort them into winter?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Show children three picture cards at a time, where one shows one season (e.g., winter) and the other two show the other season (e.g., summer). Ask, Which card doesn’t belong? Then ask, How do you know? Repeat with other groups of three cards.
Show children two picture cards at a time, where one shows summer and the other shows winter. Ask, What is the same and what is different about these pictures? Repeat with the other pair of cards.

Encourage children to use a physical response in addition to speaking. For example, invite children to wrap their arms around themselves to show cold weather or wipe their brow to show hot weather. These physical and verbal cues will support language learners and help them participate as their language skills develop.
Have children move to show you whether the answer is “summer” or “winter.” For example, they may stand for summer and sit for winter, or move to a different side of the room for each answer.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read The Changing Seasons and connected it to Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy. We learned more about the seasons.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of apple trees at different times of the year. We will talk about the pictures and put them in order, going from spring to summer to fall to winter.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to use the Make a Connection Hand Signal if a card shows something that they can connect to their lives or from the book or poster. Model.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the questions on the back of the card, offering extra support if needed.
Extend Use the last question on the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to put where it belongs in order. The cards should go in the following order: spring, summer, fall, and winter.
Repeat Continue the activity with the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: The trees change during the different seasons. Where are the apples and leaves in winter?
Have you ever seen trees like this? Have you eaten apples? Do you like them on their own? In applesauce or apple cider?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: If children are confused about the order of the seasons, help them by making spring, summer, fall, winter labels. Decorate these labels with simple pictures and then review what happens during each season.
Invite children to tell an original story about the apple trees and what happens around them. Encourage them to draw pictures to go with their stories.

Give children extra time for peer-to-peer conversations about the seasons. Review with children the names of the seasons in English, using the label cards you made. Then have them work in pairs to put the picture cards in order. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they know when talking to a child who is also multilingual.

Offer children the opportunity to respond to the activity using pencils, crayons, or markers. Be sure to provide colors that will match the trees shown on the cards (white/pink for apple blossoms, red for apples, green for leaves and grass, and so on). Encourage children to draw and use as many describing words as possible.
